Situation1: They prepare a structured session to teach important skills before a project deadline.
Expectation2: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation2: The call volume is light, and supervisors allow flexible timing for breaks.
Story: I sat at my desk, the clock ticking closer to the hour I’d promised my mentee, Sarah, a session on project management—something she needed before tomorrow’s big deadline. I’d spent my lunch break preparing slides, determined to give her the best guidance I could. Sharing what I’d learned over the years felt important, almost like a duty. But as I was about to log into our video call, my supervisor’s message pinged: “Light call volume—take your break now if you want.” The telemarketer in me knew this was a rare chance; if I didn’t take my break now, I might not get another window, and missing scheduled breaks could mean a warning. I stared at the screen, torn. Sarah was counting on me to help her succeed, but my job demanded I follow the rules and take breaks when allowed. My heart pounded as I weighed the responsibility of being a mentor against the strict expectations of my telemarketing role, feeling the pressure of both worlds closing in.
